title: Why don’t bosons follow the Pauli exclusion principle? What is the physics behind this? - Quora

response.answer_text: Essentially, because the argument that does make fermions follow this principle doesn’t hold. Let me review the argument. [Kinda. I’m skipping a bunch of details that make this argument actually work, but it should work for a conceptual picture.] When you swap the place of two fermions, your system goes to “minus itself.” If those fermions were in the same place, then your system would be equal before and after the swap (since you didn’t do anything), so the system would have to be equal to minus itself. But that means that your system is equal to zero, which means your system doesn’t exist. Now, bosons fail right at the beginning. When you swap to bosons, by definition, your system goes to itself, not minus itself. Thus, you can’t conclude that a system with two bosons in the same place is “zero”; therefore, such states are allowed. Thus, since there’s no reasons bosons couldn’t be in the same place (unlike fermions!), bosons don’t have to obey the Pauli exclusion principle.
